content: Hi @T-compiler/meeting; the triage meeting will happen tomorrow at 2020-11-12T15:00:00+00:00
WG-prioritization has done pre-triage in #t-compiler/wg-prioritization/alerts
@WG-prioritization has prepared the meeting agenda
We will have checkins from WG-rfc-2229 and WG-rls2.0
@Matthew Jasper @nikomatsakis do you have something you want to share about @WG-rfc-2229?
@matklad do you have something you want to share about @WG-rls2.0?
Yup, will post summary later today, thanks for the ping @Santiago Pastorino ! I'll need edit access to the hackmd tho
what's your HackMD username?
@matklad you are already part of the org, so you should have access
:sweat_smile: looks like actually logging in helps
right :)

Santiago Pastorino said:

do you have something you want to share about @WG-rfc-2229?

@Aman Arora would you have time to add some notes there?
I'll do that
done
Hi @T-compiler/meeting, triage meeting will be starting in ~ 30 minutes
Check out the meeting agenda
surprisingly this time the agenda is a bit light, feel free to nominate some issues you may want to discuss and let me know so we add them to the agenda
I won't be able to attend today :'(
Hi @T-compiler/meeting! Add a :wave: emoji to show you're here :)
from what @Santiago Pastorino said above, I am very hopeful that we will get through all of today's agenda. That would be amazing to do two weeks in a row!

we will start off with 5 minutes for ...

Announcements
• Tomorrow friday 13th is rustc RFC backlog day
/me still needs to write up a doc for that.
(is that a sync zoom meeting again?)
oh. That's a good question
I think that was the intention
but @nikomatsakis is not here now
well worst case scenario I can host it on my zoom
if that's the case, would be nice to clarify when exactly happens?
My vague recollection is that we were intending to run it in a similar manner to last week's steering meeting that was also on Zoom
the calendar event is set to the whole day and not to a specific time
@Santiago Pastorino oh really?
My expectation was that we would hold it in the same slot as the usual Friday meeting
yes, I thought it was an async thing that we would be running all day
oh .... that was definitely not my expectation

pnkfelix said:

My expectation was that we would hold it in the same slot as the usual Friday meeting

ok ok, so it would be 2020-11-13T12:00:00-03:00
um, no I don't think so
er that is not the right time
ohh right, my timezone shifted, anyway sorry
okay, so I guess I need to make a writeup, schedule a zoom, and fix the rustc calendar
A bit late today, but anyway :wave:
so, more annoucements!
• Next Thursday 19th we are releasing Rust 1.48

• New MCPs (take a look, see if you like them!)
    • No new proposals this time.

• Old MCPs (not seconded, take a look)
    • "Decentralize queries" compiler-team#277
    • "Require users to confirm they know RUSTC_BOOTSTRAP is unsupported before using it" compiler-team#350
    • "Accept RFC 2951 "Linking modifiers for native libraries"" compiler-team#356
    • "MCP: move compiler/ crates to stable Rust" compiler-team#358
    • "Add 32-bit and 64-bit stderr/stdout files for ui tests" compiler-team#365
    • "Add a NOOP_METHOD_CALL lint for methods which should never be directly called" compiler-team#375
    • "MCP: More Cranelift-friendly portable SIMD intrinsics" compiler-team#381
Oh, by the way: We've invited @bjorn3 to be an official compiler contributor, and @bjorn3 accepted

"Require users to confirm they know RUSTC_BOOTSTRAP is unsupported before using it" compiler-team#350

The PR that came out of this finished FCP and is just waiting for review: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/77802
/me still needs to update the team metadata for @bjorn3 's addition

oh, that reminds me -- we will branch future 1.49 stable sometime tomorrow/early this weekend, most likely (https://forge.rust-lang.org/release/process.html#bump-the-stable-version-number-t-6-days-friday-the-week-before)

• Pending FCP requests (check your boxes!)
    • "Drop official support for Windows XP" compiler-team#378

• Things in FCP (make sure you're good with it)
    • "TypeVisitor: do not hard-code a ControlFlow<()> result" compiler-team#383

• Accepted MCPs
    • "Move graphviz code out of the compiler into external crate" compiler-team#380

• Finalized FCPs (disposition merge)
    • [T-libs] "Rename/Deprecate LayoutErr in favor of LayoutError" rust#77691
    • [T-lang] "repr(transparent) on generic type skips "exactly one non-zero-sized field" check" rust#77841
    • [T-lang] "consider assignments of union field of ManuallyDrop type safe" rust#78068

pnkfelix said:

/me still needs to update the team metadata for bjorn3 's addition

I can file a PR for you to save you some time, if you want
@Léo Lanteri Thauvin that would be super helpful, yes please
and just PM me on zulip when its ready for review
(though I don't think I even have r+ rights for the relevant repo's here)
WG checkins

@WG-rfc-2229 checkin by @nikomatsakis and @Matthew Jasper:

  • PR (#78801) in review for implementing precise capture analysis, and adding feature gate for 2229 capture_disjoint_fields
  • Known issue: Statements like let _ = x will make the compiler ICE when used within a closure with the feature enabled. More generally speaking the issue is caused by let statements that create no bindings and are init'ed using a Place expression.
  • Immediate next work: start updating MIR lowering

@WG-rls2.0 checkin by @matklad:

Nothing super big happened, the last couple of months were rather quite.

  • a lot of quality-of-life improvements, assits & buf fixes
  • rust-analyzer pre-warms caches on startup, whihc should reduce latency in some cases.
  • improved syntax tree editing infra, which powers new configurable auto-import
  • better support for conditional compilation (un-cfged code is grayed out)
  • hack to support cfg-if in standard libray.
    This is a bit of an open question: how rust-analyzer should deal with crates.io deps of std? They are not vendored into rust-src component. Might be changing soon!

Note to @matklad: The last changelog as of this checkin is https://rust-analyzer.github.io/thisweek/2020/11/09/changelog-50.html

Beta-nominations

T-compiler

• "Revert "Revert "resolve: Avoid "self-confirming" import resolutions in one more case""" rust#78784
    • opened by @simulacrum
    • r+'ed by @Vadim Petrochenkov
    • scheduled for 1.49
    • reverts rust#77421 to fix rust#77586 (error on import resolution)
(what does scheduled for 1.49 mean there? This is intended for backport to 1.48...)
/me goes to look
I think that was added because rustbot added it to the 1.49 milestone?
but I don't know why rustbot did that.
ok, that's more like "landed already into 1.49"
we milestone all PRs that merge with the release they'll get released in with no backports done

simulacrum said:

(what does scheduled for 1.49 mean there? This is intended for backport to 1.48...)

I was about to remove that text because I thought it was confusing
yeah please do
and when I do backports I adjust the milestone back

simulacrum said:

(what does scheduled for 1.49 mean there? This is intended for backport to 1.48...)

sorry this is my fault I've misinterpreted the issue :sweat_smile:

simulacrum said:

and when I do backports I adjust the milestone back

I think someone in the wg was confused because of this
@apiraino no problem, its a learning experience
i.e., the milestone is intended to reflect "what Rust release is the earliest I can expect this PR to be in"
(I'd rather have a bunch of new people learning from hiccups in wg-prioritization than have the wg be composed of 2 or 3 people who are overloaded)
so, back to the backport nom
seems like a clear approve

libs-impl

  • No beta nominations for libs-impl this time.

T-rustdoc

  • No beta nominations for T-rustdoc this time.

Stable-nominations

T-compiler

  • No stable nominations for T-compiler this time.

libs-impl

  • No stable nominations for libs-impl this time.

T-rustdoc

  • No stable nominations for T-rustdoc this time.

PRs S-waiting-on-team

T-compiler

  • No PRs waiting on T-compiler this time.

libs-impl

  • No PRs waiting on libs-impl this time.

Issues of Note

Short Summary

  • 2 T-compiler P-critical issues
    • 1 of those are unassigned
  • 45 T-compiler P-high issues
    • 29 of those are unassigned
  • 1 P-critical, 1 P-high, 0 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-beta
  • 1 P-critical, 2 P-high, 5 P-medium, 1 P-low regression-from-stable-to-nightly
  • 1 P-critical, 21 P-high, 67 P-medium, 5 P-low regression-from-stable-to-stable

P-critical

T-compiler

• "Upgrade to LLVM11 caused a codegen regression on Windows" rust#78283
    • opened by @Jeff Muizelaar
    • assigned to @pnkfelix
    • Firefox code that used to work on Rust 1.46 started to fail after upgrading to LLVM 11
    • Affects only MSVC
    • @Nikita Popov suggests could be related to rust#74498
    • @Jeff Muizelaar suggests to be related to LLVM bug #46943, provides a minimal repro
    • @pnkfelix has patch in progress for LLVM bug #46943
(this thing has been epic, yet the patch is so small and simple)
To be clear: I have not yet verified that my LLVM patch fixes the bug(s) filed on the Rust repo.
That's just a hope.
But still, its as under control as we could hope it to be.

• "No error reported when a generic parameter doesn't meet the requirement of an associated type" rust#78893
    • Nightly regression
    • Regressed on rust#73905 cc @Matthew Jasper
oh dear
we should probably revert rust#73905 before it goes into beta, no?
how much time do we have?
a day or so
the beta cut will be in a day or so?
but really, we can revert in beta too, so not sure there's a particular rush
yes
its a pretty serious regression in the static semantics, IMO
I think reverting makes sense
yea, I agree that in this case we should revert and try again
I'm just saying that getting that in before the beta cut does not seem critical
Anyone want to volunteer to land a revert? Its an easy thing for new contributors to do
Is this even a bug?
(unless @Matthew Jasper comes up with an easy fix)
/me looks again
you mean it just becomes uncallable?
so "its fine"?
this might be an acceptable change, but one that should be approved by T-lang
@Matthew Jasper is your assertion that the bound on the associated type is implied? Or that its irrelevant?
Well, callable only if on a type where the associated type meets the bound.
It's irrelevant IMO.
yeah, okay, maybe I overstated things when I said it was a "severe bug" in the static semantics; but its definitely a change. I'm still not clear on the ramifications
If people are relying on those bounds being enforced for some protocols of their API, then it seems like it could matter.
but the idea that the only drawback is that you can now write some useless code that is not callable, which is not necessarily a drawback, is understandable.
anyway, I still think we should revert in short term, and let T-lang look at it.
(I will also admit that it hurts to give up the performance wins associated with the injecting PR)
https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=nightly&mode=debug&edition=2018&gist=6aa019d744f02512ca3235d505527915 this works, which is a bit odd, but not broken I guess
There are a lot of (merged) PRs that rely on #73905
The really weird thing that works is https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=nightly&mode=debug&edition=2018&gist=864bac11e8b7ff77c4ea12c2e0fc7e4c, but I don't think we have a soundness issue here
(or even a footgun, it's just super super odd, similar to how bounds are not checked on type aliases)

Matthew Jasper said:

There are a lot of (merged) PRs that rely on #73905

That makes me worried as well, in terms of it meaning that a revert from beta will be even harder.
which makes me even more inclined to push for a revert from nightly before the beta is cut.
It sounds like it's going to be hard to revert and we should wait until we have consensus we should perhaps?
like, if there's lots of dependencies we'll end up reverting a bunch of work since then which seems bad
then the decision to revert or not might also need to take into account the unsoundness issues fixed by 73905 ?
I can try to restore the old behavior if people think that it made more sense before.
people have been asking for more implied bounds for a while, but I guess the problem is we didn't make an official decision on it?
I'm currently experimenting and the more I do, the less I think this is a bug or even a footgun at all
IIRC before this PR, there were issues with non-WF trait objects being accepted, right Matthew ?
And some other ones.
Okay. I'm willing to trust @Matthew Jasper and @oli for the short term
And let this slip into beta
I'm going to tag it with T-lang and nominate it for their next triage meeting
interestingly it's not propagated in one way I expect it might https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=nightly&mode=debug&edition=2018&gist=c7d99d88a636e141cfed99106c3dee1d
I may want help making a writeup
but this could also be because this is a separate type parameter so there's no obvious mechanism for how this might work
@oli could you maybe PM me links with the differnet play examples you've been demo'ing to yourself?
will do
(@oli along with PM's with quick notes about what each variation is trying to explore)
@pnkfelix you'll probably also need this crater report and notes about compatibility
@lqd thanks
@oli actually, rather than a PM, a separate topic would be fine (and perhaps preferable), since other people could likewise chime in there.
ok
(presumably under #t-compiler , or maybe #t-lang . What do I know.)
okay
(gee did I say we would get through the whole agenda today ...?)

libs-impl

  • No P-critical issues for libs-impl this time.

T-rustdoc

  • No P-critical issues for T-rustdoc this time.

P-high regressions

P-high beta regressions

  • No P-high beta regressions this time.

Unassigned P-high nightly regressions

  • No unassigned P-high nightly regressions this time.

Performance logs

A mixed week with improvements still outweighing regressions. Perhaps the biggest highlight was the move to compiling rustc crates with the initial-exec TLS model which results in fewer calls to _tls_get_addr and thus faster compile times.

Triage done by @rylevick.
Revision range: 5cdf5b882da9e8b7c73b5cadeb7745cb68f6ff63..cf9cf7c923eb01146971429044f216a3ca905e06

1 Regressions, 2 Improvements, 2 Mixed

Regressions

#78267

  • Small regression in instruction counts (up to 1.2% on full builds of deeply-nested-async-check)
  • This might be noise as this only affects one benchmark negatively, and that benchmark tends to be on the noisier side.

Improvements

#78280

  • Moderate improvement in instruction counts (up to -1.3% on incr-patched: new row builds of tuple-stress-opt)

#78201

  • Large improvement in instruction counts (up to -7.2% on incr-full builds of webrender-wrench-check)
  • This change may produce similar performance gains in related tooling such as rustdoc and clippy.
(just want to chime in to say thanks to @Ryan Levick who volunteered to do perf this week :)

Mixed

#77227

  • Large improvement in instruction counts (up to -5.0% on incr-unchanged builds of deeply-nested-async-check)
  • Moderate regression in instruction counts (up to 1.3% on full builds of ctfe-stress-4-check)

#78410

  • Very large improvement in instruction counts (up to -26.0% on incr-unchanged builds of deeply-nested-async-opt)
  • Moderate regression in instruction counts (up to 3.8% on full builds of ctfe-stress-4-check)
  • This change is a revert of a previous change, and at least one user was reporting massive performance gains.
(deleted)
(I should move that message, lmk when you have a topic for it)
lets just make it now
https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/213817-t-lang/topic/.2378893.20no.20err.20when.20genrc.20param.20doesnt.20meet.20req.20of.20assoc.20type/near/216485082
that is, #t-lang > #78893 no err when genrc param doesnt meet req of assoc type
okay
last part of the perf report

Nags requiring follow up

The compiler team is once again requested to look into:

  • <https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/78432#issuecomment-721388323>
(anyone want to take point on that? I'm swamped today so I don't want to volunteer.)
Oh, sorry, this was an oversight
I think we settled it last week
did we?
okay
I'm happy to move along then
Yeah, or at least, I was satisfied with a couple folks saying "not a problem"

Nominated Issues

T-compiler

• "SIGSEGV from rustc while building crate legion" rust#77869
    • Can't compile legion crate since 1.47
    • Nominated so we can try to get eyes on the root cause of the issue.
Oh
If you have easy access to a Ryzen CPU (e.g. you use one for development), add yourself to the raised hands here please
we probably should have better ways of tracking this sort of developer metadata
(I'm pretty sure @eddyb should have their hand up there. :laughing: )
anyway I'm planning to self-assign this, I'm happy to devote some spare cycles on my Ryzen to this now that it can stop churning on my LLVM hacking.
welp sorry, I was on the other thread

pnkfelix said:

we probably should have better ways of tracking this sort of developer metadata

Would a notification group make sense?
no problem @eddyb , I was just giving you a hard time. :smile:
@Léo Lanteri Thauvin I don't know
we have access to an EPYC 7xx1, presumably it could also reproduce? (wow, serious dejavu)
it looks like it might make sense for an intel cpu user to try and reproduce, fwiw
since we do have reproductions on amd
but anyway seems fine
there are times when I think what I want is a matrix describing the different dev machine characteristics. Or maybe a full-on SQL db. :)
a few intel users tried to reproduce in another thread and couldn't
@simulacrum well i guess it depends on whether our goal is to dive deeper into the known repro's, or to learn more about the other cases.
but in any case, @lqd makes a good point.
anyway I don't think we need to go more into that here.

eddyb said:

we have access to an EPYC 7xx1, presumably it could also reproduce? (wow, serious dejavu)

wait, what's the deja vu here?
(I'll link to the thread in a sec, zulip search is slow don't mind me :) edit: https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/131828-t-compiler/topic/rustc.20SIGSEGV
just the general instances of weirdness that only replicates atop Ryzen boxen?
I guess I'm remembering the znver1 bug
anyway, hopefully I or someone else can make headway on #77869

libs-impl

  • No nominated issues for libs-impl this time.

RFC

  • No nominated RFCs for T-compiler this time.
and we're done!
7 minutes to spare even
we could all spend the 7 minutes compiling legion in parallel. :laughing:
oh yeah, #63959, but that was windows, so the EPYC server was no use
Why not, I can try on my intel system.
Hey, I have a short announce relevant for folks working with #![feature(rustc_private)] proejcts
https://github.com/rust-analyzer/rust-analyzer/pull/6524 adds support for this to rust-analyzer
(not merged yet, but will be merged soon). So, ra should work better when hacking on miri, clipy and the like
will let the Rust-GPU folks know :D

bjorn3 said:

Why not, I can try on my intel system.

100 tries of the second snippet in https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/77869#issuecomment-710714256 doesn't reproduce the issue as I expected.
maybe the recent rr fixes for ryzen could help with diagnosing this for the amd users who can repro

pnkfelix said:

#78201

  • Large improvement in instruction counts (up to -7.2% on incr-full builds of webrender-wrench-check)
  • This change may produce similar performance gains in related tooling such as rustdoc and clippy.

Indeed it did, webrender-wrench-doc is down 6.2% :)
@lqd ah yes a tool in search of a bug
okay all, now I do have to go
thanks to everyone in @T-compiler/meeting for attending!
I've created the agenda meeting for next week https://hackmd.io/qJb6ljabRaGixAnWNwp1TA?both
we will have checkins from @WG-self-profile and @WG-traits cc @Wesley Wiser @nikomatsakis
also cc @Jack Huey if they are involved in WG-traits
They are
https://github.com/rust-lang/team/blob/master/teams/wg-traits.toml#L6 they are
@Santiago Pastorino the WG leads seem much more up-to-date on rust-lang/team rather than rust-lang/compiler-team which is where I assume you're looking ?
right, I think it may be a good idea to make a PR to compiler-team repo and adding a link to the team repo from there rather than listing the leads
I'll take care of it, I see that heavy "hint hint wink" :) -- edit: done

pnkfelix said:

okay, so I guess I need to make a writeup, schedule a zoom, and fix the rustc calendar

(I have now done parts 2 and 3 of the above. Still need to prepare a writeup.)
